lead_paragraph: Acting as independent arbiters to shape government policy, many researchers also have corporate roles that are sometimes undisclosed.

byline.contributor: Brooke Williams is a reporter at the New England Center for Investigative Reporting, which collaborated with The New York Times on this series. Kitty Bennett contributed research.
byline.original: By ERIC LIPTON, NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and BROOKE WILLIAMS

headline.print_headline: Top Scholars or Lobbyists? Often It’s Both
headline.main: Think Tank Scholar or Corporate Consultant? It Depends on the Day

snippet: Acting as independent arbiters to shape government policy, many researchers also have corporate roles that are sometimes undisclosed....
abstract: Examination of 75 think tank researchers finds that many also worked as registered lobbyists, members of corporate boards or outside consultants in litigation and regulatory disputes; their undisclosed dual roles raises questions over possible conflicts of interest (Series: Think Tanks Inc).

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Center for Strategic and International Studies
